justification: The article states that "Instrumental harm can be measured using sacrificial dilemmas, reflecting one key way that utilitarianism departs from CSM."

measured_by: Oxford Utilitarianism Scale – Impartial Beneficence subscale (OUS-IB)
justification: In the Glossary the authors explain that "The OUS-IB subscale consists of 5 items tapping endorsement of the impartial maximization of the greater good."

measured_by: Oxford Utilitarianism Scale – Instrumental Harm subscale (OUS-IH)
justification: The Glossary notes that "The OUS-IH subscale consists of 4 items tapping a willingness to cause harm in order to bring about the greater good."

topic_or_construct: Proto-utilitarian concern for the greater good
measured_by: U-parameter derived from Process Dissociation of sacrificial dilemmas
justification: The text explains that Process Dissociation can "identify a subset of pro-sacrificial judgments (the 'U-parameter') that does reflect a genuine concern for the greater good and is therefore meaningfully utilitarian."

measured_by: D-parameter derived from Process Dissociation of sacrificial dilemmas
justification: Box 2 describes the D-parameter as reflecting "those with relatively stronger harm-rejection tendencies (the 'D-parameter') who consistently reject causing harm in the dilemmas."
